Homophobia is ...
 
 a range of negative attitudes and feelings towards lesbian, gay, bisexual, XXXXX, and in some cases transgender and intersex people. Definitions refer variably to antipathy, contempt, prejudice, aversion, and irrational fear. -- Homophobia - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 
 Intense hatred or fear of homosexuals or homosexuality -- World English Dictionary
 
 irrational fear of, aversion to, or discrimination against homosexuality or homosexuals -- Merriam-Webster Medical Dictionary 
 (Both of the above at Homophobia | Define Homophobia at Dictionary.com.)
 
 
 a term used to describe irrational fear of, aversion to, or discrimination against homosexuals.It can also mean "irrational fear of, aversion to, or discrimination against homosexuality or homosexuals".Webster's 
 Online Dictionary
 
 Also from the above:
 
 
Psychologist George Weinberg introduced the first scholarly use of the concept homophobia in his 1972 book Society and the Healthy Homosexual,published one year before the American Psychiatric Association voted to remove homosexuality from its list of mental disorders... He describes the concept as:
 "a phobia about homosexuals....It was a fear of homosexuals which seemed to be associated with a fear of contagion, a fear of reducing the things one fought for-home and family. It was a religious fear and it had led to great brutality as fear always does."
 Conceptualizing prejudice against gay and lesbian people as a social problem worthy of scholarly attention was not a new concept, but Weinberg was the first to give the problem a name.

 You brought up some great points I think. 
 It's ok to question gay pride dogma (just as it is ok to question religious dogma) and these are good examples.
 
 The issue of the term 'homophobia' is interesting. A lot of the gay pride approach has been to try and own terminology. "Homophobia", "bigot", "equality", etc. are all terms thrown out there in the debate as rhetoric, and are rarely qualified. 
 The reality is, if homophobia is evil, then most PEOPLE are evil. The example I use is the tendency of 2 guys to keep an empty seat between them in the movie theater. Let's be honest--the reason they do it is often because of homophobia, or not wanting to be perceived as gay. (There are other reasons too of course, such as having more room) Now is that evil? I don't think so. What is clear is that the same term should not be used to both describe a.) leaving an empty seat in a theater, and b.) beating a gay person to death. Yet it is. The term is too broad to be meaningful. As such it becomes an attack term, to try and vilify or to just throw around. My conclusion to the fact that homophobia would mean most people are evil is that the premise 'homophobia is evil' is not necessarily the case. The 'ick' factor is actually probably pretty natural. We're going to obviously be turned off by sexual activity that doesn't fall under our own sexual orientation. Gays have 'ick factors' to varying degrees over heterosexual sex as well. Is that bad? I don't think it falls under the auspices of good or bad, it just IS. It's a state of being.
 It's when people ACT on homophobia and allow it to influence them to go out and physically harm gays that it becomes a problem.
 
 Your second point is correct too that it is a misnomer when they say 'gays cannot marry.' Of course, what they really mean is that gays can't marry a person of the same gender. But you are right, in that they technically DO have the same right that an opposite-gender couple has. This is why, in my opinion, the real issue is that gays want to change marriage. 
 
 The third point you make is yet another problem with gay pride movement arguments .... using the fact that 'the animals do it' to argue that it's natural. The important question SHOULD be, is it natural for PEOPLE to do it? 
 Animals engage in all sorts of behavior--for instance, some animals many kill and eat their young. Does that make such to be natural behavior for people? No, I don't think it does. Humans operate on a much different level of behavior and so it is unnatural if a person engages in such animal behavior. "Because-the-animals-do-it" is, in fact, a terrible argument for normalcy on this topic or most any other.
 
 Your 4th point gets back to the issue of the gay pride movement wanting to own terminology. "Gay" now has gone through 3 meanings in the last few decades: 1. glad; 2. homosexual; 3. dislike or asinine. Indeed, if one is going to argue that they should be able to own a term because language changes, then they have to accept that they may lose a term because language changes. However, to be fair, I haven't heard too many gays too upset over this. Maybe they are, I don't know. I just haven't heard any of them say so.

Just as the word "theory" has different meanings that are often--whether unknowingly or deliberately--confused to argue against, say, the Theory of Evolution, so the word "pride" has different definitions that can be confused--unknowingly or deliberately--to denigrate gay people.
 the quality or state of being proud: as a : inordinate self-esteem : conceit b : a reasonable or justifiable self-respect c : delight or elation arising from some act, possession, or relationship <parental pride<-- Merriam-Webster Dictionary
 In the context of "gay pride," the intended connotation by those who coined the term, and by gay people in general, is b.
 
 Anti-gay people, however, frequently tend to cast it in the light of the first, less admirable meaning.

 Allah (Arabic: الله‎ Allāh, IPA: [ʔalˤːɑːh] ( listen)) is the standard Arabic word for God. The term is best known in the West for its use by Muslims as a reference to God in the context of Islam. It is also used by Arabic speakers of all Abrahamic faiths, including Mizrahi Jews, Bahá'ís, Eastern Orthodox Christians and Eastern Catholic Christians, in reference to God.
 The term Allāh is derived from a contraction of the Arabic definite article al- "the" and ʼilāh "deity, god" to al-lāh meaning "the [sole] deity, God" (ho theos monos).[4] Cognates of the name "Allāh" exist in other Semitic languages, including Hebrew and Aramaic.Biblical Hebrew mostly uses the plural form (but functional singular) Elohim.  Yet the founders were smart in knowing this might be the case: they included a means to account for this possibility: amending their constitution. We need to be careful to use the founders' built in means to account for these values changes (amendments) rather than using other means to circumvent the means they built in. If we were to actually follow historical precedent (imagine that!), gay marriage would come about via amendment. After all, that's how womens' suffrage, voting rights, and the freedom of black people came about. 
 
 I do think though that there is far greater room for error in making sweeping changes based on social mood than sticking to the founders' original intent. Whether something is was a mistake on the founders' part is very subjective, dependent on social climate and values as they change with time. This is why they made amendments a hard process. Constitutional change shouldn't come on a whim, but we shouldn't try to circumvent the process, either.
